Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAngela Rayner is set to tell the Labour Party it must win or die in a fiery speech setting out her bid to be deputy leader.The straight-talking Shadow Education Secretary, will tell Labour members how she will bring the party together after its catastrophic election defeat as she launches her bid to become deputy leader in her native Greater Manchester.She will warn against ato the vanilla politics of the past in a nod to the radical overhaul of Labour under Corbyn. But Rayner, who left school at  without any qualications, will say that Labour should avoid using the language of revolution. The outspoken MP has been credited with pushing Labouraposs National Education Service and championing the Sure Start centres introduced by the last Labour government which helped her to go back to education after dropping out to raise her son. Making her pitch at the Community Centre in the Bridgehall estate where she grew up and brought up her son as a young mum, will say that Labouraposs call for change must be presented as common sense change people can believe in. Rayner, who became political through the trade union movement will unveil support from across the party including Shadow International Trade Secretary Barry Gardiner and shadow policing minister Lou Haigh. Highlighting the scale of the challenge facing Labour, Ms Rayner will point to seats across the UK that, in a matter of years, have gone from “heartlands to battlegrounds” and where people have felt the Party has “lost touch with them” She will warn: “The gap between generations has never been starker. Our coalition, the foundation of our party, is broken.   “This crisis has been a long time coming and we’ve kept avoiding it. It is the biggest challenge in our history.” Ms Rayner will go on to say that the next five years will be “the fight of our lives” but one that the entire Labour movement must tackle head on. She will say: “The quick fix of a new leader will not be enough.We must rethink and renew our purpose and how we convince the people to share it.Either we face up to these new times or we become irrelevant.The next five years will be the fight of our lives and I’m standing here today because I don’t run away from a fight.” The Shadow Education Secretary was expected to go for the top job but stood aside to help Rebecca Long-Bailey -  her close friend and flatmate.The deputy leader post has been vacant since before the general election , when Tom Watson announced he was quitting Parliament.Ms Rayner, who is widely considered the frontrunner, is expecting to be challenged by Shadow Justice Secretary Richard Burgon and shadow sports minister Rosena Allin-Khan.The deputy leadership race has so far been overshadowed by the race to succeed Jeremy Corbyn who announced he was standing down  in the wake of Labouraposs crushing defeat, when the party won just  seats - its worst election performance in more than  years.He will stay on in the post until the end of March, while a new leader and deputy and are chosen.

title: angela rayner wants deputy labour
story: NewsAngela Rayner wants to be deputy Labour leader for the girls growing up on her estateThe Shadow Education Secretary launched her campaign on the Bridgehall estate in Stockport where she grew up and where the community stepped in when she and her family were strugglingShareByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN News" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAngela Rayner has dedicated her campaign to be deputy Labour leader to the girls growing up on her estate. She said: I wanted the young girls in particular on this estate to know they are me and I am them and that was so important to me that I came back and acknowledged the role the estate has had on me. Launching her campaign to succeed Tom Watson in her native Stockport she paid tribute to the community where she grew up and who stepped in when she and her family were struggling. But it wasnapost just the people that made a dference- it was the policies of the last Labour government that made Rayner the success she is today - a fact sheaposs been at pains to make despite hostility from some within the party. Speaking at the Bridgehall Community Centre, she said: The dference between me and Boris Johnson is Iaposve walked into a room and Iaposve never been the one that people assume is the natural leader - Iaposve always had to earn the right to speak on behalf of my members and my constituents. Rayner explained how much it meant to do the the launch where she grew up. It was so important to me that I came back here and acknowledged the role that this estate has had on making me the person I am today, she said. Rayner has made no secret about the dficulties her family faced. Neither of her parents were working and she and her siblings used to make the twenty-minute walk to her nanaposs every week for a hot bath. But sheaposs also been open about the support she needed. Itaposs a real sense of community here. I remember as a young child being on the park there and me and my mate - whose mum and dad had substance and alcohol problems she didnapost like being at home very much either and I was thrown out never to be seen and weaposd sit in freezing cold rain underneath the slide together chatting trying to keep warm together in our tiny skirts and little white socks that we used to wear - although they were grey.  Sitting in the community centre that the last Labour government built she lights up as she speaks about where sheaposs from. Pointing out the houses and the playground around the centre, she said: I walked my sister to school here from around the corner and what was nice is, because it was an estate, everyone knew everyone.  She said: I still know everyone. I came back here to do a video and everyone was coming out of their houses to say aposhiyaapos and some of the people I grew up with have got their children on the estate. When she left school she had her son Ryan and got a council flat on the estate. The community helped me raise Ryan for the first few years of his le, she said. It makes me feel really warm - itaposs really nice to be here back on the estate. But there is clearly still a part of her that canapost believe how far sheaposs come. For years Rayneraposs upbringing was seen as a disadvantage. She dropped out of school at  when she fell pregnant with her first child and battled to go back to education. But now she sees it as her strength - helping her to navigate a tempestuous time in politics and the Labour Party especially. My skills - one of the reasons I am running for deputy leader - is that I think my skills are about unity and bringing people together. And actually, I think I learnt all of those things as a young person on this estate. Living in poverty, living on an estate, it can be quite rough. It can be quite jostly, dficult and conflicting, she said.  I learnt how to navigate all of that on this estate, and I think those are the skills as I said in my speech that Iaposve really taken into politics. And itaposs probably why Iaposve thrived so well in what has been quite a turbulent time for most politicians. Iaposve actually quite enjoyed a bit of the chaos. Thereaposs no doubt Rayner has thrived - managing to confound detractors who said she wasnapost educated enough for her shadow cabinet role and digging her heels in when it came to making sure her national education service and early years got the focus she wanted in the partyaposs manesto. But some of the internal battles have not been easy. She explained: What I donapost enjoy though is fighting, bullying, and not getting into government because I didnapost go into Parliament to be a protester. I went into Parliament to make change. Because I saw the change that happened on this estate with a Labour government.  Rayner is clear that the bullying sheaposs seen in the party over recent years has got to stop She said: I experienced a lot of bullying. Iaposve seen it at dferent levels of the party. Culturally the party got into a position where it was internally frustrated, it didnapost know what it stood for. There was a power struggle going on in the party where one side would think it was more righteous than the other. Thataposs not acceptable. Weaposre the Labour Party and we canapost accept that anymore. Weaposve got to call it out.With her pitch to unite the party itaposs clear why she wonapost name names but thereaposs no doubt Rayner knocked heads with some of those around Jeremy Corbyn to whom personally sheaposs stayed fiercely loyal. And itaposs that loyalty that explains one of the reasons she wouldnapost go for the top job against her friend and flatmate Rebecca Long Bailey. She said she “took offence on behalf” of Becky who often gets described as “continuity Corbyn” adding: “one thing I know about Becky and you will know soon,you don’t already, is she is her own woman”. Thataposs a question few will need to ask of Rayner. On her personal politics sheaposs clear.

title: brexit law rushed through week
story: NewsBrexit law rushed through this week as Boris Johnson plots exit day celebrationThe Withdrawal Agreement Bill will pass through the House of Commons in just three days - as No dropped a heavy hint that Boris Johnson has "plans" to mark the moment we leave on January ShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN NewsBoris Johnsons Brexit Bill will be rushed through the House of Commons in just three days " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBoris Johnsonaposs Brexit Bill will be rushed through the House of Commons in just three days this week  - as the Prime Minister draws up plans to celebrate exit day.Downing Street confirmed the timetable today despite concerns that three days will not be long enough to pass the Withdrawal Agreement Bill, one of the last steps for Brexit to happen on January .MPs previously refused to let Mr Johnson rush the massively complicated Bill through in three days - prompting him to call an election. Now that heaposs won an -seat majority, the Prime Minister can spend as little time on the aposWABapos as he likes. That is despite MPsapos concerns not disappearing about the Bill, which waters down previous pledges on workersapos rights and contains a apostrapdoorapos to no-deal Brexit on January . Meanwhile Downing Street dropped a heavy hint that Mr Johnson plans a celebration event of some kind to mark the moment the UK exits at pm on January . Dozens of Tory Brexiteers have already called for Big Ben to chime at pm while Nigel Farage is planning a Brexit day party outside Parliament, which could include fireworks, bands and comedians. Today the PMaposs official spokesman said: We will set out our plans shortly but I don’t have anything for you yet. Askedthe PM did plan a commemoration of some kind he added: It’s clearly a signicant moment in our country’s history. We’ll set all of our plans out, hopefully as one, shortly.” The Commons begins three days of debates on the Withdrawal Agreement Bill on Tuesday, with the deadline for the UK’s departure set for January . The Government’s -strong majority means Opposition MPs have little chance of amending the legislation, which is being debated at committee stage. The Conservative leader is set on railroading through his exit deal after winning last month’s general election with a pledge to “Get Brexit Done”.The Bill must pass through the Commons and Lords and receive Royal Assent from the Queen by the end of this month so the UK an leave at pm on January . An -month transition begins immediately, during which British and EU officials aim to thrash out an agreement on the future relationship between the UK and bloc. Mr Johnson hosts new European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen in No on Wednesday after Prime Minister’s Questions in Parliament.  “The purpose really is to have an introductory meeting,” said the PM’s spokesman. Mr Johnson is expected to push the Brussels chief to commit to striking a trade deal by the end of this year. Ms von der Leyen has previously spoken of her “serious concern” at the demand a pact could be reached within the -month timetable. No said: “Where minds should be focused is on the fact that the EU jointly agreed with the UK that it would do everytthing to conclude an ambitious future partnership by the end of .

title: dominic cummings flouts greenest country
story: NewsDominic Cummings flouts greenest country on Earth pledge with paper coffee cupAnd sustainable drinkwear wasnt the only problem Boris Johnsons closest advisor had this morning - he also appeared to have struggled to get dressedShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsDominic Cummings drank from a cardboard cup " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDominic Cummings was spotted this morning working hard on the Boris Johnsonaposs promise to make Britain the aposgreenest country on Earthapos by glugging coffee from a disposable coffee cup.Paper cups, which are dficult and costly to recycle, have long been looked down on around the cabinet table - not least by former Environment Secretary Michael Gove .Mr Gove famously distributed reusable plastic coffee cups to cabinet members during Theresa Mayaposs time in Number . In a memorable moment at Septemberaposs Tory conference in Manchester, Mr Johnson himself was berated by an aide as he prepared to take a sip from a paper cup. And just hours after winning Decemberaposs election, the PM vowed to make Britain the cleanest, greenest on Earth, with the most far-reaching environmental programme”. Apparently his pledge does not extend to his most senior advisor, who strode into Number  proudly swigging from an environmentally unfriendly recepticle.And that wasnapost Mr Cummingsapos only problem. He also appeared to have struggled to get dressed. Resplendent in an attention-grabbing bright orange jumper, Mr Cummings wore a pair of baggy blue jeans the likes of which have not been seen since the Happy Mondaysapos heyday. And not to put too fine a point on it, he hadnapost fully prepared for his jumper riding up, exposing his...ahem...lower back to waiting cameramen. Earlier, Mr Johnsonaposs spokesman admitted the PM backed Mr Cummingsapos bizarre job advert for “weirdos and misfits” to shake-up Whitehall. Mr Cummings issued a ,-word job advert via his blog last week asking “true wild cards” to apply for No roles. But he warned potential colleagues: “I’ll bin you within weeksyou don’t fit — don’t complain later because I made it clear now.” Union leaders blasted the call while others warned it risked politicising the famously impartial Civil Service.  The PM’s spokesman: “You can see that the Government is committed to levelling up across every part of the United Kingdom to making sure that we make the most of all the skills which people in this country possess, and we will take whatever innovative steps are required to be delivering that.” Asked directlythe PM “sanctioned” the blog post, the spokesman replied: “The short answer to that is yes.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabouraposs leadership race kicks off on Tuesday  January as Jeremy Corbyn steps down over the partyaposs worst general election defeat since . Runners and riders have been jostling to make their vision heard as they prepare to face off in a contest that will define the future of the Labour Party. Who wins will be defined by Labouraposs ,-ish members - many of whom flocked into the party after  to support Jeremy Corbyn and his left-wing agenda. Long time ally Rebecca Long-Bailey is seen as the aposcontinuityapos candidate to carry Mr Corbynaposs torch - but some in the party fear she wonapost make enough of a splash and want party chair Ian Lavery instead. Remainers Emily Thornberry and Keir Starmer have declared their intentions while Wiganaposs Lisa Nandy, a backbencher who warned for years that Labour could lose northern heartlands over Brexit, is also in the frame. A new leader will be in place on April . Here are all the candidates and potential candidates so far. The new leader will be announced on Saturday  April after a three-month contest to pick the next Labour chief. Candidates will have until Monday next week to gain the support of  MPs - plus either % of constituency parties or % of affiliates . Those who get onto the ballot paper will then face a vote by full members, union affiliates and registered supporters. Members and union affiliates will have until pm on Monday  January to sign up for a ballot. Or people can sign up for a one-off vote as a registered supporter for £. To do this they have just a -hour window to sign up for a vote in the leadership race - between pm next Tuesday and pm next Thursday. The rule is the same one that was used in , when more than , registered supporters applied in two days.Runners, riders and betting odds Declared they will definitely run KEIR STARMER,  -   Holborn  St Pancras  PROFILE: The favourite in internal polls of Labour party members - and is popular among the broader public with Tories privately admitting they’d rather he didn’t get the job. While the shadow Brexit Secretary’s Remain inclinations will no longer be a problem, being a North London man might be. He’s not a union man, but has their respect, and has an impressive CV as he was Director of Public Prosecutions before becoming an MP in . His seriousness and intellect help at the despatch box, but he could do with sometimes showing his lighter side. WHAT HEaposS SAID: He warned the party must not oversteer back to the centre. He said: The case for a radical Labour government has never been stronger”. And he called for the party to take on the narrative that Boris Johnson can aposget Brexit doneapos by the end of January.  LISA NANDY,  -   Wigan  PROFILE: The eloquent backbencher was first elected to Parliament in  having worked for homelessness charity Centrepoint and then as senior policy adviser at The Children’s Society. She has been credited as one of the Labour MPs who “gets it” over Brexit, understanding why many Labour supporters in her Greater Manchester seat backed Leave. The half-Indian politician is a member of the Centre for Towns think tank. She quit the frontbench in the aftermath of the Brexit referendum and her attempts to try to break the Brexit deadlock won her plaudits on all sides of the Commons. Her links with powerful Union unite could help any run. Has hinted at a joint bid with David Lammy. WHAT SHEaposS SAID: She argued Labour is facing the last chance to save itself as a whole, not from warring factions, and win back older and working-class voters. Itaposs about whether that traditional coalition that has propelled us into power three times in the last  years can hold good, and whether we can speak for both Lewisham and Leigh.  JESS PHILLIPS,  -   Birmingham Yardley  PROFILE: The powerful voice is one of Labour’s strongest media performers who has the ability to speak “human” and the ability to tack between funny quips and powerful speeches. She is the chair of Labour’s women’s PLP and has been a strong supporter of all-women shortlists - perhaps suggesting she could push for them to be extended to the leadership race. But as she admitted herself on election night, the leadership race is “more than just a personality game and I know that people like me because I have a personality, and that will never just be enough.” WHAT SHEaposS SAID: “Now is not the time to play it safe. What I’ve heard so far in this debate is totally inadequate to the scale of the problem. Voters have changed, the electoral map has been transformed, communication in a social media age is dferent. We need to recognise that politics has changed in a fundamental way by electing a dferent kind of leader. More of the same will lead to more of the same result.”  CLIVE LEWIS,  -   Norwich South   PROFILE: A former BBC correspondent Mr Lewis has straddled the ide in the Labour party between Corbynistas and more moderate MPs. He resigned as shadow Defence Secretary after attempts by Mr Corbyn’s office to water down the party’s support for Trident. But the Norwich South MP has also been a vocal supporter of many of the soon to be ex-Labour leader’s policies. The shadow business secretary’s quiet demeanour belies a fiery passion for addressing social justice. Laura Pidcock’s failure to win a seat has cleared the way for her to be the candidate of the Left. She says sheaposs seriously considering running for the leadership - and will back flatmate Angela Rayner for the deputy leadershipshe runs. WHAT SHEaposS SAID: The MP confirmed she is “considering” a leadership run and will back Angela Rayner for deputy in an apparent joint ticket. Defending Jeremy Corbyn’s legacy, she wrote in the : “Our transformative agenda is principled and popular, while triangulation and soft pedalling will only take us backwards. We didn’t lose because of our commitments to scrap universal credit, invest in public services or abolish tuition fees.” However, in comments which will be seen as an attempt to dferentiate herself from the Labour leader, she wrote: From ex-miners in Blythe Valley to migrant cleaners in Brixton, from small businesses in Stoke-on-Trent to the self-employed in Salford, we have to unite our communities. Britain has a long history of patriotism rooted in working le, built upon unity and pride in the common interests and shared le of everyone. To win we must revive this progressive patriotism and solidarity in a form fit for modern Britain.  Tipped to run IAN LAVERY,  -   Wansbeck  PROFILE: A bruiser who began his career at Northumberland’s Lynemouth Colliery, Ian Lavery was thrown into politics by the s Miners’ Strike. The -year-old succeeded Arthur Scargill as National Union of Mineworkers President in  before becoming an MP in . The Jeremy Corbyn loyalist, whose region backed Leave by % to %, was one of the few Shadow Cabinet ministers to adamantly back Brexit after the  referendum. That led to clashes between the father-of-two, a football, cricket and boxing fan, and top MPs who wanted to Remain. Despite being Labour’s joint elections co-ordinator since , Mr Lavery very nearly paid a heavy personal price over Brexit. His , majority in Wansbeck was slashed to  in the general election as a ‘red wall’ of Labour heartlands turned blue.Mr Lavery was previously dogged by press coverage about £, he received from a union he ran, which by  had only  recorded members. The money included just under £, in termination payments”, when Mr Lavery was made redundant as general secretary of the NUM Northumberland Area on becoming an MP in May . Mr Lavery has always vehemently denied wrongdoing, either by himself or the union, and the Certication Office for trade unions decided not to investigate further in an October  report. WHAT HEaposS SAID: Talk of a second referendum was seen by many as a way to foist Remain upon them. Communities represented by Labour for generations felt abandoned. It is time to outline a positive vision of the future outside of the EU. Divided parties can’t win. Let’s get back to debating in a forthright but respectful way, remembering what we have in common and stop reinforcing press attacks on our own party.  DAN JARVIS,  -   Barnsley Central  PROFILE: The state-educated son of a lecturer and probation officer went to Sandhurst and served in the Parachute Regiment in Kosovo, Northern Ireland, Iraq and Afghanistan, rising to the rank of Major. He resigned from the Army to fight and win a by-election in . Despite being tipped for stardom in the days of Ed Miliband, heaposs had a very low profile under Jeremy Corbyn - even though he is juggling two elected offices, as MP and Mayor for the Sheffield City region. Ruled themselves out, or are set to pull out YVETTE COOPER,  Pontefract  Castleford  PROFILE: Yvette Cooper saw her odds slashed from   to   after she said she was considering throwing her hat into the ring. She is seen as a competent politician having chaired the Home Affairs Select Committee and with respect from MPs from the parliament. But four years ago she lost to Jeremy Corbyn . The former Cabinet minister who came second in the contest in  winning % of the vote compared to Mr Corbynaposs % said she would decide over Christmas whether to enter the race. Ms Cooper, who saw her majority in Normanton, Pontefract and Castleford slashed from , to , last week, said the party needed to move away from the politics of both Mr Corbyn and Mr Blairit was to win back the support of patriotic older voters who abandoned it for the Tories. We cannot just become a party that is concentrated in cities, with our support increasingly concentrated in erse, young, fast-moving areas while older voters in towns think we arenapost listening to them, WHAT SHEaposS SAID: She said both the left and right of the party are seen as internationalist rather than patriotic and Labour mustto its support in towns and former heartlands, not just the erse young fast-moving cities in England. However the Mirror reported she was unlikely to run after taking soundings from colleagues.  ANGELA RAYNER,  Ashton-under-Lyne  Long tipped for the top job, her back story of rising to the top of politics despite leaving school after getting pregnant at  is inspirational. She later trained as a care worker and eventually became a trade union representative with Unison, who would be likely to back her for the top job. The shadow education secretary has become an increasingly polished performer, but Labour insiders claim that she is still a work in progress. But sheaposs going for the deputy leadership instead. Nor was it about the career prospects. I was never going to sell housesthe future of the free world depended on it. It was about entering the big, bad world of work as a -year-old and all the independence that came with it. So news that the traditional Saturday job is dying out comes as a great shame. I filed, filled out contact sheets, put together details of properties to go on the market and, of course, made the tea. It taught me about le, about people and the value of hard work. It gave me an insight into the ying approaches dferent people take to the same job. I’ve met versions of the characters in that estate agents in east London in every workplace I’ve been to since. Teenagers passing up the opportunity to get an early insight into the way the world works are losing out big time.

Sam Hemingway, , also scrawled the words aposKunta Kinteapos and aposTobyapos - referring to a slave character in TV show Roots - before giving the pizza to driver Nathaniel Ramsey. Mr Ramsey was entitled to a free pizza as part of his job for the takeaway firm - but twice found racial slurs written on the side of his boxes. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA top celebrity chef has revealed his best tips for making mashed potato - and the most common mistakes we make when cooking it. MasterChef host Marcus Wareing, who runs Michelin-starred restaurant Marcus, has shared his mash method in his new book Marcus Everyday. Mashed potato, a British dinner staple, are usually served as a side dish to meat or vegetables and can be made using peeled or unpeeled potatoes. Milk, butter, salt and pepper are frequently used in preparation to add flavour to the mash. But itaposs not easy to perfect. In his recipe compilation, the cook urges readers to follow three steps. “Cut evenly, cook evenly and don’t rush”, he advises. The TV chef adds that many make the mistake of cutting their potatoes to dferent sizes, the Daily Star reports. Other common errors people make are boiling them too quickly and failing to leave them to rest. Here are some of the cookaposs tips for a perfect mash... . Cut the potatoes evenly  Marcus Wareing says it is important to peel the potatoes cleanly, then wash them and make sure they are cut into evenly sized piece. This is because,they are dferent sizes, the smaller pieces will overcook and they will absorb water, which can make your mash tasteless. . Boil them slowly The potatoes need to be cooked in salted water at a slow boil. If boiled fast, the outside will be overcooked before the middle of the potato chunks is cooked through. This will create dferent consistency in your mash and make it unpleasant. . Leave them to rest  Once the potatoes are cooked, you should drain and leave them for a good five minutes. After shaking them around, you can put them back in the pan, off the heat. Once they have rested, the potatoes are ready to be mashed to your liking, adding butter, cheese or herbs. A potato ricer helps in the process of making mashed potato. Most people use Russets for mashed potatoes because of their high starch and low water content, according to Simply Recipes . Yukon Golds, which are a little more expensive than Russets, are another popular alternative as they are naturally creamy when mashed and have a slightly buttery flavour of their own. Marcus explains: “First, peel the potatoes cleanly, then wash them and cut them all into evenly sized pieces, otherwise the smaller potato pieces will overcook, and before they break they will absorb water, which will make your mash watery and tasteless.  “Boil them in salted water at a slow boil – a fast boil will overcook the outside before the middle of the potato chunks are cooked through you don’t want lumps of overcooked potato in your mash. “Once the potatoes are cooked all the way through, but not quite falling apart, drain and leave them for a good five minutes, then shake them around and put them back in the pan, off the heat. “The potatoes should then be hot enough to take the butter on board.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is what le is like on Benefit Street six years after the landmark show first aired on Channel . The hard-hitting show documented the daily lives of people living in James Turner Street in Winson Green, an inner-city working class area in Birmingham - warts and all. Residents in the bustling street were seen trying to make ends meet evenmeant breaking the law by shoplting, committing benefit fraud and growing cannabis. The nation was hooked and tuned in to watch the ins and outs of people living in the Victorian terraced houses including Deidre Kelly , Samora Roberts , Smoggy , James Clarkeand Lee Nutley. Six years on and the street is a a quieter place with new families residing in the properties which were once home to those who stared in the documentary, Birmingham Live reports. However, the street still has its issues with litter scattered across the pavements, fly-tipping and homes blighted with mice infestations. One mum-of-two was moved to James Turner Street by Birmingham Council after she was deemed homeless and in need of temporary accommodation. She said: I said I didnapost care where I lived, I just wanted a roof over my head, until I came here. Every time I step out my door, thereaposs litter everywhere. Iaposve only been here since July, Iaposm trying to get out.  I was homeless and living in a Travelodge. At least it was nice and clean in there. We had a mice infestation here, but we got a cat so thataposs sorted it.  Many of the residents are in a similar situation and said they had been moved to the street by housing associations or the council. A dad-of-five said his family were moved to the road from Richmond, south west London, because he couldnapost afford the capitalaposs prices. The move meant leaving family members behind, but he has made new friends on the street - which he says still retains its community feel, despite its problems.  He said: I was terried at first, all Iaposd ever heard about Birmingham is itaposs a s*** hole, donapost go there.  Iaposve been through so much. Iaposm just happy to have a roof over my head, evenitaposs a s*** one. But the people are nice. The other night they all come out, everyone was out watching the fireworks. Itaposs a nice community, itaposs not like London,you dropped on the floor, theyaposd walk past you, here theyaposd stop and help. Everyone says hello, youaposve got the odd couple, but it is nice. I do like the people. He has lived in the street for three years and has noted a number of disturbing incidents, including a-year-old girl forced to move with her family after being sexually harassed, a delivery driver being carjacked and a family unable to wash their  kids for more than a year.  I wish Iaposd come here [Birmingham] earlier, just not this street, he said. Iaposve seen a gentleman get out of his car bringing a food delivery, and as he got out, one of these lads jumped in it and drove off. He also said one family who lived across the street survived with no running water and no electricity for a year-and-a-half. The people, they donapost deserve to live in the s*** theyaposre living in. Because they are living in filth, he said.  There was a family up the end there, there was a lot of them. The landlord done f*** all. Not a f***** thing. They must have had  kids and they never had a wash as long as they were here. You would see and smell them walk past, it would break my heart. Some of these people, I can see in their face they are just depressed. Some of the people are the closest to animals I have ever seen people be. One -year-old girl, the boys would not leave her alone. In the end the police had to get involved, they had to move them.  Speaking about illegal dumping on his street, he said: It seems like itaposs just left, once it gets in a mess, they leave it a mess. You canapost leave nothing out,I left my buggy there, went in for half an hour, Iaposd come back and guarantee itaposs gone. His partner added: Theyaposd rob the eyes out of your f***** head. Basoz Ali moved into the street with her family after their landlord in Perry Barr asked for their property back.  The young family, who have two children, are living in temporary accommodation with the council. The -year-old said: Itaposs so dficult, we feel like weaposre ignored. We feel neglected. We work hard and we deserve better place to live. Weaposve got a lot of mice, we have to block all the holes in the house, but still they find ways to come in because of the messiness. They throw food bags, all their waste, evenits not rubbish day. In the house, the mice ruin everything, they ruin the shopping and I have to throw a lot of good stuff into the bin.

Yet Orlaghaposs made an unlikely comeback to the point that sheaposs now a level one skying instructor and sheaposs hugely grateful to everyone thataposs supported her, including people in her local town of Bray who donated money to fund her treatment. I wasnapost expected to recover as quickly or as fully as I did, andI had the stress of a financial burden that we couldnapost afford I am very confidentthat my brain wouldnapost have recovered as much as it did, and in such good time, she explained.

title: cammy its time dee realise how good they can be
story: Cammy Kerr says it’s time the Dundee squad realised how good they can be as they embark on what they plan is a positive .The Dark Blues ended  on a positive note after a strong showing in a - draw at rivals Dundee United followed up back-to-back wins against Dunfermline and Partick.After a calendar year to forget at Dens Park, Kerr plans to use their recent good run to hit the ground running for the second half of the campaign, starting tomorrow at home to Inverness.He told the Tele: “ wasn’t a good year.“Even as a young boy coming through when my first season full-time was the ‘Club ’ season. That was a dficult time.“We’ve had loads of ups and downs but the past year is certainly one, for the first half of it anyway, we want to put behind us as quickly as possible.“With the recent bit of form and positivity, we take that into  and kick on.”Dundee start the year with three home matches on the bounce, firstly against potential play-off rivals Caley Thistle and Ayr United before they welcome high-flying Premiership side Motherwell to Dens Park for a Scottish Cup tie.“We have dficult games coming up. We have three games at home now and we need to get back to making this place a fortress,” Kerr added.“I said it at the start of the season that,we wanted to do anything in this league, we’ve got to make our home form much better than it has been.“It is better than it has been over the past year but it’s still not where we want it to be.“That’s something we are working so hard every day to put right.“Every game we go into, we expect ourselves to win. That’s not being arrogant or cocky but what Dundee should be aiming for.“There needs to be a realisation of how good this squad can be.”And Kerr says the second half against league leaders United last Friday gives everyone associated with the club belief they can start looking upwards.“There was a wee realisation after the game we could have taken three points.“The boys have spoken since and we’re starting to realise how well we can do as a team.“After we got the goal at Tannadice, there was a belief on the pitch and I think the fans felt that.“Even when the board went up for how long was left, the fans still thought we could win it.“Hopefully, that is a wee turning point for us – it needs to be going forward.“There has been a lot of disappointment, a lot of games where we have huffed and puffed throughout the season.“Last Friday, the fans came again in their numbers and I didn’t expect there to be so many, to be honest.“United had three of the stands but our fans were so loud again and when we scored it was great to go and celebrate with them.“Our fans have had to endure a dficult year, especially with United being on top since day one.“We are happy with how it went but, at the same time, we need to make sure we don’t rest on a draw – we need to remember we didn’t win – but use it to kick us on.”Dundee have faced the Caley Jags three times this season, winning -, drawing - and losing - last time in Inverness.Dundee United - Dundee: Dorrans# first goal earns Dee derby point" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-united---dundee-dorrans-first-goal-earns-dee-derby-point embed # secretynOUlpvmC" data-secret"ynOUlpvmC" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Kerr added: “We are under no illusions how tough it will be tomorrow. Inverness are second for a reason.“They beat us last time. I was on the bench that day but the boys won’t mind me saying we didn’t do ourselves justice.“We huffed and puffed, had loads of possession but we weren’t good enough on the day to be the team everyone wants us to be – we need to make up for that.”

title: dee utd team of the decade the best of 2010s
story: Greg Stewart or Johnny Russell  Gary Mackay-Steven or Gary Harkins  Darren O’Dea or Sean Dillon Who is the best we’ve seen in the City of Discovery over the past  years As we head into the s, Tele Sport writers George Cran and Calum Woodger looked back over the decade and, after a debate on the Twa Teams, One Street podcast, brought together the EveningTeam of the Decade.Goalkeeper: Scott BainArriving at Dens Park a year before the club won the Championship, Bain made himself club No  in the Premiership.After  appearances for the club, Bain left for Celtic and has played three times for Scotland.Defence: Gary IrvineA favourite among Dundee fans who crowned Irvine ‘the White Cafu’ after a flurry of goals from right-back, the defender made almost  appearances for the club.Defenders: Sean DillonA modern day club legend, ‘Dillo’ spent more than  years at Dundee United, winning the Scottish Cup in .He went on to captain the club for four seasons in the top-flight before departing in  after making  appearances in tangerine.James McPakeDillon and McPake shook hands six times as captains in Dundee derbies, with the United man getting the better of the results.McPake, though, is remembered as a player for two derby goals – one in a - win for his side and the second a late leveller at Tannadice.He may only have made  appearances for the club before injury ended his career early but McPake’s leadership on the pitch earns him a place in this team.Andrew RobertsonVery little has to be said about this choice – Robertson was a star in the making at Tannadice.Arriving as an unknown -year-old from Queen’s Park, Robertson swtly made the left-back place his own and became well-known for rampaging runs down the flank.Just a year later, he was off to Hull City for £. million and has since become a European Cup winner with Liverpool and Scotland captain.His  games for United brought five goals.Midfielders:Gary Mackay-StevenThe wing wizard edged out Dundee favourite Gary Harkins for the right-wing berth in our team.‘GMS’ was an entertainer with an array of tricks and flicks and was a major part of the free-flowing football that made the Tangerines a regular top-six outfit under Jackie McNamara.Stuart ArmstrongArmstrong and ‘GMS’ were inseparable at the top end of Scottish football for years before the former moved down south to Southampton.Armstrong’s athleticism and ability on the ball made him the focal point of United’s attack during six years at the club from  to .Kevin ThomsonHe may only have played  times for the Dens Park club.However, Thomson’s ability and nous in the middle of the park played a huge role in Dundee’s top-six finish in -.Craig ConwayA man scoring two goals in a Scottish Cup Final win is a must for a team like this.A compact, tricky attacker, Conway went on to enjoy a fine career for himself down south after making his name at Tannadice.Strikers: Greg StewartPlucked from Cowdenbeath, Stewart was arguably Dundee’s Player of the Decade.Shortlisted for the - PFA Scotland Players’ Player of the Year award, Stewart terrorised Premiership defences in dark blue.Twenty-two league goals in  top-flight matches from his time at the club is a sizeablewith his trademark curled finishes a regular sight at Dens Park.Jon DalyAnother Scottish Cup winner in his time in the city, Daly was a colossus for Dundee United.A real targetman, Daly was key in the early part of the decade with - a bumper year with  league goals in the top flight after winning the Scottish Cup in .The Irishman managed  goals in just over  games for the club –  of those goals came after .Manager: Peter HoustonShortly after taking over from Craig Levein, Houston led the Tangerines to a famous Scottish Cup triumph in  – only the second United manager to ever lt the trophy.Have your say on Tele Sport’s choices by emailing sport@eveningtelegraph

title: dundee united 1 1 dundee dorrans first goal earns dee derby point
story: Graham Dorrans# first goal for Dundee earned his side a point as they came from behind at Tannadice to end Dundee United#s derby dominance.Nicky Clark had given league leaders United an early advantage but Dorrans rled home the equaliser in the second period to end the Terrors# nine-game winning streak and perfect derby record this season.Dundee were unchanged from their win over Partick last weekend while Louis Appere replaced the injured Sam Stanton for United.And it was the Tangerines who got off to a dream start in front of a , near-sell-out, scoring with the first attack and shot of the game after just five minutes.Appere released Jamie Robson on the overlap down the left and the full-back#s delivery was flicked home by Clark for his seventh goal of the season.Action threatened to boil over on  minutes as Robson and Dundee#s Paul McGowan exchanged handbags in the corner but referee Alan Muir kept his cards in his pocket.And it was McGowan who had the Dark Blues# first real chance of the game on  minutes.The -year-old picked up on a Jordan Marshall cut back, twisted and turned in the box to make some space but saw his shot deflected behind for a corner.On  minutes McGowan was again denied by Siegrist inside the box as he collected a lovely reverse pass from -year-old Fin Robertson but couldn#t find a way past the big Swiss.Terrors talisman Lawrence Shankland had his first clear-cut chance of the game  minutes before half-time but couldn#t head home from six yards out after Robson#s delivery.Calum Butcher escaped a booking on two counts as he went in heavy on Danny Johnson and McGowan as tempers began to flare as the game approached half-time.Dee keeper Jack Hamilton did well to deny Ian Harkes from close range to keep the score down at the interval.Much like the opening period, there was an early goal to start the second half # and it was Dundee who got it.Five minutes after the action restarted Dorrans got on the end of Liam Smith#s clearance to rle home a left-footed volley for his first goal for the club.With the match level, the Dark Blues almost took the lead moments later as Johnson was inches away from getting on the end of a Sean Mackie cross.On  minutes, Shankland went close as he nodded Paul McMullan#s cross just wide of Hamilton#s left-hand post as both teams pushed for a winner.However, both sides had to settle for a point apiece as they go into the new year United sitting top and Dundee in play-off contention.Dundee United XI : SiegristL Smith, Watson, Reynolds , Robson Butcher, Harkes, McMullan, Clark , Appere Shankland.Subs not used: Deniz , Connolly, C Smith, Chalmers, King and Mochrie.Dundee XI : HamiltonKerr, McGhee, Meekings , Marshall McGowan, Robertson, Dorrans, Mackie Hemmings, Johnson .Subs not used: Ferrie , Forster, Todd, Byrne, Moore and Mulligan.Ref: Alan Muir.Att: , .

title: proof the honours system is now morally redundant
story: We are at the dawn of a new decade and, under normal circumstances, that would fill me with feelings of hope.Yet it was overshadowed by the sense that the last  years was something of a lost decade.It was a decade that will forever haunt me because of the wounds inflicted upon men, women and children as a direct result of the Welfare Reform Act .And to see the dying embers of this decade snuffed out by the knighthood of its chief architect, Sir Iain Duncan Smith, left me lost for words.The Welfare Reform Act is a piece of legislation that will live long in the memory.It took effect on Monday April   and tightened the sanctions regime for people who failed to comply with their new claimant commitment.It included the under-occupancy penalty – or bedroom tax – which deducted sums of money from anyone with a spare bedroom.Then there was the most reprehensible reform to welfare since the birth of social security, Universal Credit. That is just a small introduction.Ironically, the legislation was conceived in Scotland. Back in  my friend, the late, great socialist Bob Holman, invited Mr Duncan Smith, then Tory leader, to visit Easterhouse in Glasgow.So apparently moved was he by what he saw in those tenement blocks that Mr Duncan Smith established the Centre for Social Justice , which became the conceptual cradle for many a Conservative policy he later embedded in legislation in his role as secretary of state for work and pensions.My we informed me that a petition had been uploaded calling for the revocation of his knighthood and had attracted fewer than , signatories.I told her it would be up to more than , in less than a day – the number needed to secure a House of Commons debate.Two days on and it hit ,. One signatory, Lynne Saunders, wrote: “This man should be prosecuted for murder, not knighted.”At the time of being published, almost a quarter of a million people had signed, calling for Mr Duncan Smith#s knightood to be revoked. I would hope there is a debate and that it includes the fact that foodbank use in Scotland rocketed by % in the year after the Act became law, and the story of the mum I met in Paisley who gave up breastfeeding her six-week-old because she was too malnourished following an administrative error that withheld a benefit payment.The truth is, the greatest heroes often go unsung and the honours system we currently have is just another farcical seam in an imperial tapestry that is becoming increasingly redundant in the eyes of a growing number of people in Scotland.My friend Bob, who sadly died in June , shared my view on the honours system.He turned down an MBE in  due to his belief that it promotes dferences in status.Now that, I believe, is worthy of honour.

story: Aberdeen council tenants have under four weeks left to give their views on the introduction of a new fixed-term rent policy.Aberdeen City Council has launched an online survey about the move, which could allow residents to plan ahead financially.Currently, rent is set at the council budget meeting each March, which can make budgeting challenging for both tenants and the council.If implemented, both parties will know what the rent increase will be on their property for a number of years.The local authority claims the advantage of a long-term rent policy is that it allows tenants and the council to plan ahead financially, knowing what the rent increase will be for a number of years.If a new policy comes into effect, councillors will bring in a policy which would apply for three years when they meet to set their budget this year.Rent paid to Aberdeen City Council is held in an account known as the Housing Revenue Account .The money in this account can only be invested in housing services such as repairs, improvements, housing management and building new properties.Tenants have until January  to complete the survey, which can be found at https:bit.ly mCfbj

story: Children have fun and develop their skills at a north-east nursery, inspectors have said.Monitors from the Care Inspectorate watchdog visited Celtic Cross Nursery on Station Road, Banchory, on November  and have now published their report.The nursery can look after up to  children aged up to five and inspectors rated it “good” for care, support and staffing – the third best of six possible ratings. “The nursery has a vision to provide a safe, stimulating, happy and nurturing environment,” said the report.It added: “The service placed a strong emphasis on the desire to help children reach their full potential, building them to be confident iniduals, respectful citizens, successful learners and effective contributors.”Inspectors praised staff for giving children lots of opportunities to learn outside.The report said: “Outdoor play was a key strength of the service.“Children were stimulated, having fun and developing skills through a iety of interesting outdoor experiences – for example, pretending to cook with mud and leaves and building dens.“Children were also developing an awareness of safety as they participated in positive risk experiences such as balancing on wooden planks.“Children were becoming more resilient through these experiences.”Inspectors asked parents for their views on the service.The report said: “All parents agreed they were overall happy with the quality of care their children were receiving. title: meet rg mowat owner of the fulmar
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAt the end of November we asked readers for help to unravel the mystery of a yacht log book which was posted to the paper with no clues as to its origin.And, not for the first time, Argyllshire Advertiser readers have come up trumps and we now know a little more about the boat#s owner, named only as RG Mowat in the log book.The  log book gives an account of the voyages of the -foot gaff cutter #Fulmar# and the adventures of her colourful crew. Its dog-eared pages contain neatly-typed records, precise drawings and fascinating photographs.The log#s mystery is deepened by the fact no names are given other than the nicknames #Tanky#, #Bosun#, #Skipper# and #Pilot#. The only crew member named is pet dachshund #Major#.The log does record the Fulmar#s home port was Tighnabruaich and the owner was RG Mowat, but few details on Mr Mowat could be found.Lord Weir of Lochhead, Achahoish, contacted the newspaper to pass on information on Commander Ralph G Mowat.During the Second World War, Commander Mowat was a Royal Navy Captain, latterly in command of a cruiser. At the end of the war, he and his ship entered Copenhagen, where he took the surrender of the German troops.Clive Brown from Ardfern added some post-war detail. He revealed: #Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , was a distinguished member of Clyde Cruising Clubbest known as being, for  years, the honorary editor of the CCC Sailing Directions . These were # and indeed remain # a #must have# for everyone who navigates their way among the many lochs and islands of Scotland#s west coast. They were colloquially known as the #Blue Book# and published at that time as a hardback. He also served as CCC Rear Commodore -.#Mr Brown also provided an extract from the book #Clyde Cruising Club, The First One Hundred Years -# which states Ralph Mowat received an RYA Award for services to yachting in  but refused to accept honorary membership of the club. In recompense, his widow Mary was elected an honorary member in , after his death.Tighnabruaich man Alan Wilson contacted Clyde sailing legend Ian Nicolson, who was fairly sure he recalled racing against the #Fulmar# in the s.Mr Nicolson said:#Old Man Mowat, as I remember him, was a typical ex Royal Navy officer. He treated me as a young upstart, which I was, but we got on well because I wrote a bit for Clyde Cruising Club publications. He lived in Clarkston on the edge of Glasgow.#Clyde Cruising Club itself cannot help with information on the Fulmar. Club secretary Jenner Rollands contacted the Advertiser and confirmed CCC sadly lost all its records when the Carrick, moored on the River Clyde, sank in . At the time, the club#s office was aboard her.Closer to home, Ardrishaig man Billy Paterson called into the Advertiser offices to say his father, Ardrishaig Primary School headmaster Gilbert Paterson, had crewed the yacht Fulmar.Mr Paterson still has mementoes from his father#s trips in the form of gts from Commander Mowat, including a paperweight from , a copper and brass barrel ashtray dated  and a brass model yacht with #Fulmar # engraved on it.Thanks to everyone who contacted the Advertiser with their memories.We now know a little more about Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , owner of the Fulmar.Details about the crew of #Tanky#, #Bosun# and #Pilot# remain, however, sketchy, soanyone out there knows any more#

title: news from the districts january 3 2020
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe Scottish Salmon Companyhas provided Cowal Badminton Association with funding towards new sporting equipment following its latest round of Community Fund awards.Cowal Badminton Association received a £ donation to cover the costs of rackets and shuttlecocks for their new practice nights.The association was founded almost  years ago, playing a vital role in bringing the community of Dunoon together by offering weekly social events that are inclusive to all.Development co-ordinator at Cowal Badminton Association, Craig Anderson, said: #The funding from SSC has enabled us to purchase new rackets and tubes of shuttlecocks, which our members will be able to use. We hope this will remove a barrier to new members joining, as they will no longer have to provide their own equipment. On behalf of the team, we thank the Scottish Salmon Company for its kind donation.#Volunteers are being offered a chance to work off some of the seasonal over eating, as a work party is held at Tarbert Castle.Meeting at am tomorrow , the group will set about planting trees and removing brambles until around lunchtime.The perfect opportunity to catch up following the festivities, all willing to help will be made welcome and tea and coffee will be on offer to the hard working volunteers.A #Scandinavian# approach to self-sufficiency is being proposed by Craignish Community Council.With Argyll and Bute Council being unable extend their gritting areas, community council members picked up bags of grit from the council depot. Four bags have been placed by the Glebe houses, five up Ardlarach Road on the pavement nearer the top and three for the steeper bits on the road up to Lunga.Empty bags can be handed into Ardfern Shop and they will be re-filled.In a Facebook post Craignish Community Council said: #It seems that in future we may be best taking the more Scandinavian approach of managing it ourselves for those areas beyond council gritting.#The weather was chilly but dry for the Boxing Day shinty match in Strachur, attracting a good number of spectators .In the annual under-s versus over-s clash, the old boys just about squeaked it - after an exciting match at Strachurmore Sports Centre.Veteran Ally Mirrlees opened the scoring with a well-taken goal just five minutes into the match. Ten minutes later Lewis Montgomery levelled matters, before another from Montgomery beat over-s keeper Ross MacDonald to give the youngsters a half-time lead slimmer than most of the waists in the opposition ranks.The game was to turn in the second half, as Neil Nicolson scored twice for the old boys and the victory was theirs, despite goalie Willie McGladdery pulling off some good saves for the under-s.The Niall Campbell Memorial Trophy was presented to winning captain Ross MacDonald by Mr Campbell#s son John, and a very sociable evening followed in the Strachurmore pavilion.PIC:All smiles after an entertaining match to blow away the festive cobwebs. no_aStrachurBoxingDay

title: a bumper year for rallying
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards was a big year for Argyll locals with the much anticipatedof one of the biggest events in Scotland on the doorstep, Mull Rally, and the continued running of the Mach  Stages and Argyll Stages in Dunoon. Three events all within a stones throw of Mid Argyll.Jamie Miller was the only local to enter this event, starting his Scottish Tarmac Rally Championshipcampaign for the year in the rapid  Citroen CR. Paul Hunter, swapping his pacenotes for spanners, was on hand to assist Jamie throughout the season. Conditions were said to have been tricky as Knockhill has its own micro-climate, which consists purely of rain, wind, snow, ice, wind and wind. Sadly it wasn#t to be at Knockhill for the team with mechanical failure ending their day after stage two.The first closed road event to take place in England, after the approval of closed road rallying for the UK, was the first event for the famousGTi. Unfortunately for Kirsty Mochrie her licence can only be upgraded to stage events from single venue use when she turns , so it was theof the pairing of Innes Mochrie and Paul Hunter to represent Mid Argyll south of the border. The pair, finding the conditions tricky in the narrow lanes after the top seed cars had been pulling mud from verges and ditches, managed to bounce the wee metro over the first loop of four stages until the gearbox had enough on the fth test.Following the cancelling of Inverness# Snowman Rally earlier in the year, this was now first round of the Scottish Rally Championshipfor Dougie Watt and Ian Parker, and it was interesting to say the least. A glance outside in the morning to see about four inches of snow lying on the roof of the MK Escort was a surprise for a start. A very wet and muddy day saw the pair make it to the finish in one piece which is more than can be said for the clutch cable that snapped about one mile into the final stage, however clinching their first class win of the season was the best start to the championship.With Kirsty #Wee Mo# Mochrie in the co-drivers seat in the rapid Corsa of Steven Hay , a fair pace was set by the pair throughout the day sitting as high as th until they unfortunately had to take a split early to save damaging the car. Back out the next stage and still setting a blistering top  pace in the Corsa, including some hang time on both the jumps.Jamie, back out in the fit C, had bad luck once again. This time an overshoot on a square right and a struggle to get the car started again after a stall sadly earned him a stage max on stage two. Still setting top  times on the day he ended nd which was a fair effort when you include a stage maximum time.Ian was out this time with Fraser #Flat oot Fraz# Smithafter winning an entry to the rally at the STRC Awards in January. Flying out the gates and onto their second lap on the first stage then pop, driveshaft burst. Towed in and sorted, both covered in CV Grease, they made it back out for a skid around and on a mission to tear up some old tarmac tyres.The Granite Stages, now held at RAF Leuchars would see Eoghan Anderson make ato the passenger seat for a hurl in the immaculate MK Escort of Martin Murray. Smiling ear to ear all day, with Bill eagerly awaiting histo the service area for the stage report, they finished th overall.Ian was out with Greg Inglisin his fluorescent Orange Lotus Exige and it was eyes on the prize for STRC points for Greg. A clean day saw Greg really getting to grips with the car on some surprisingly fast stages including a tickle of the limiter in fth saw the pair finish third overall.Back together and with the small repairs from the Speyside done it was time for the Furnace MK toto the woods. A steady run over the opening two stages, Dougie and Ian found their feet after the #off# at the Speyside sent them into service lying th. From seeing their overall position they knew they had to get back into it on the next stage, however on the road section to start stage three there was issues selecting gear and the pair decided to call it a day # damage limitation was the right call, as the input shaft was on its last legs.Jamie was back on the pace for this one, setting a th fastest stage time on the opening test. Sitting th overall heading into stage five was impressive given the competition on the day. Bad luck unfortunately, however, was to .Eoghan was again out with Martin in the MK for a blast. Sadly it was an early bath, retired after stage two but again, as always, enjoying every minute while it lasted.The Argyll rally had been known to have rough and challenging stages the previous two years. Not this time. Ian and Dougie couldn#t believe how good the stages were in comparison to previous years, an absolute joy of an event with the Escort not missing a beat all day on its #shakedown# for the big one. Valuable class points added to the scorecard too, with them ending the event nd overall. The rally had struggled with entries this year and will now run in  as a closed road rally, run by Mull Car Club.Team Mochrie were back together for this one in the Mightyagain and Innes was cutting some questionable shapes in the garage, performing his annual Mach rain dance. Taking chunks of time from his first passes of the stages would see them ring the #s neck and clinch th.Jamie#s luck had finally turned, the C singing all weekend and netting him a topper of th overall and th fastest over the final stage too.Duncan Maclean was back in the driving seat with Ian alongside, giving himself and the car a shakedown before Mull. The freshly rebuilt #blue bullet# was looking superb and managed to finish looking just as sweet. A couple of small teething problems were sorted on the day and the new main focus was to have power steering fitted before Mull # poor Dochy lost about a stone over two days with the effort needed to swing the wee pug around the #s and chicanes.In August Dougie and Ian competed on the Vetomies Rally. A national grade event run alongside the WRC Rally Finland event. Three other crews from Scotland also headed over to sample #the fastest rally in the world#. The stages were unbelievable. Fast, cresty, wide, flowing with a brilliantly smooth surface. The whole event was just surreal. The duo finished the event th overall and more importantly the fastest Scottish crew.Once the car had ed from Finland it was quickly jacked up, checked and loaded onto the trailer the same day for the journey north. Due to two DNFson the Speyside and Scottish, Dougie and Ian had to make the trip to be in with any chance of regaining their class lead in the SRC. Ending the day first in the class meant they were heading into the final round with the lead.Jamie was back out for another counting round of the STRC. Enjoying his day and pushing the wee C on in the blistering heat netted Jamie and co-driver Ian Mccullochrd overall. He must have been relaxed in the heat as in between stages he was off with the overalls and on with the baby lotion, topping up the tan.Ian was back out with Greg in the Lotus. Another fantastic drive from Greg, finishing ninth with the championship title race firmly the primary goal.The final round for the MK and an important one # a DNF here could see Dougie and Ian losing the class lead in the championship. A battle with their rival who they had been chasing all season, Paddy Munro, would come down to the last stage, as the pair were six seconds down on Paddy heading into the final test. Probably one of the duo#s best stages all year, the final push to claim the class honours came down to the finish of the last stage on the last rally of the year. One second! They had taken the class win and the championship.The first event this year for Craig Callander and son Ross would see them prepare Craig#s gravel spec Subaru Impreza at the last minute to take on their favourite event. The #Japanese Tractor# was a fair handful, a light steering alignment issue and a boost problem gave the pair some trouble although finishing th overall made up for the hassle. A fair result given Craig#s absence from tarmac for four years.Returning from the shed with his freshly painted Sunbeam was Alister Macarthur, this time with Claire Tilleyalongside. The freshly fettled #beam was looking and sounding good # crossing the finish th overall after two years out of the seat.Dochy and Ian were back out in the #blue bullet.# All was going well until they had a spin coming over a crest into a square left, losing the bumper and damaging the gear linkage. They managed to get the car back to the end of the Saturday afternoon leg to repair the gear linkage and almost stole the yellow bumper from the recce car until some legends appeared with the duo#s bumper in the back of their Land Rover. Back out onto the  mile #long one# on Saturday night and they had an issue # after a heavy landing over a crest the rear shocker bolt broke, making the car a handful to keep in a straight line. They had to finish another two stages before they could make it back to service, so a finish was all they wanted at this point # th overall and Dochys fourth finish in a row on Mull.Without doubt the driver to watch was Innes and his newly acquired co-driver Lewis Grfiths . The Mightywas spotted airborne at any chance, with the hydro can suspension screaming for a break at each service halt. It was almost all over as the nearside cv joint sheared and the car took a wild turn to the left # both Innes and Lewis thought they would end up IN the Belachroy pub. They managed to make it over the Lochs to the end of the final stage, claiming st overall.Eoghan was back out with Martin to settle the score from the DNF at the summer stages. Sadly a stage maximum time on stage two scuppered their chances of the overall result they were hoping for, however they did set some impressive times, clocking a th fastest time on the final stage.Jamie, back out for the final round of the STRC, was looking to continue his good run from the Pendragon and set a seventh fastest time on stage three in the extremely wet and tricky conditions. Trying to get his money#s worth from his entry fee Jamie, however, decided to take an extra couple of miles on the penultimate stage. Still, the C ran well all day and the conditions suited the car perfectly.Ian was back out with Greg and this time he was aiming to become the Scottish Tarmac Rally Champion for . They set off with five cars in the same class and they had to win the class to get Greg the honours. Setting the pace early they were leading throughout the event. Finishing the event first in their class and third overall meant the job was done # Greg claimed the championship win.The last event of the year saw Kirsty back in the co-drivers seat, gaining even more experience on her path to upgrading her licence. Some typical Knockhill weather was in store as Kirsty had her first taste of RWD rallying in the Mazda MX of Paul Sheard. Kirsty guided Paul around the very wet stages to claim th overall and some valuable points on the board for Paul#s Motorsport News Championship campaign.Special thanks to Alasdair MacConnell who has travelled many miles to don an orange bib and stand in the rain, wind and heat, all to show his support and play a vital part in any event. And to Gavin #Top Tog# Brown, who has been an avid rally man for years and continued to watch us all through the lens, capturing some of our most heroic moments. was a busy year, with a few of us still tinkering away in sheds.  will hopefully see theof Ally and Del Galbraith in their #new# MK Escort and Donald Bowness in the giant killing Nova making aafter some time out.PICS:Dougie Watt and Ian Parker flying in Finland before winning in Aberdeen Photo: Jii Pihlaja. no_a_RallyFinlandFather and son duo Craig and Ross Callendar came in th overall at this year#s Mull Rally. Photo: West Coast Photography. no_aMullRally_CraigCallanderEuan Thorburn took a drama filled Argyll Rally victory, adding to his  win on the event. Photos: Eddie Kelly Motorsport Photography. no_aargyllrallyInnes Mochrie, Lochgilphead and Lewis Grfiths finished Mull Rally st overall. Photo: West Coast Photography. no_aMullRally_InnesMochrie

title: bute meets ayrshire in memory of calum
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAn Argyll and Bute charity has joined forces with the Prince#s Foundation to offer families living with cancer short getaways at a five-star, self-catering cottage at Dumfries House estate, East Ayrshire.Caroline Speirs co-founded Calum#s Cabin with her husband Duncan and daughter Jenna to provide holiday homes on the Isle of Bute for children suffering from cancer or a cancer-related disease. Caroline and Duncan were parents to Calum, who sadly passed away aged  after being diagnosed with a brain tumour.Knowing he and his family lived in a beautul part of the world, Calum wanted children suffering from cancer to come to Bute for special getaways where the entire family could cherish quality time together and recharge their batteries for what may lie ahead.The charity now runs several holiday homes on Bute and private flats in Glasgow for families travelling to the city for treatments at the Beatson West of Scotland Cancer Care and Royal Hospital for Children.Dumfries House Lodge is a -room, five-star country guest house with two self-catering cottages, all staffed round the clock.Eight families have been referred through the children#s charity so far to enjoy a four-night stay free of charge.Caroline said: #To allow Calum#s Cabin families to be helped in such a special way is an absolute honour. For many of the families who have had this opportunity, their conditions would have been too severe to get away on holiday, or to come to Bute, so Dumfries House is perfect. Sadly for some, it has been their final holiday together.#The families have been blown away by their stays at Dumfries House. The peace and tranquility of the estate make it an ideal getaway and the staff could not have done more. Our families have come away from each break with unforgettable memories and a renewed energy and focus for whatever may come next.#Louis MacCallum, director of commercial for the Prince#s Foundation at Dumfries House, said: #Anyone who has met Caroline and Duncan cannot fail to be inspired into helping their charity in any way they can. Being a Buteman myself, I was already aware of the wonderful work of Calum#s Cabin on Bute and in Glasgow and was delighted to help.#

title: rileys-christmas-spirit-send-teejay-back-blackpool
story: THE spirit of Christmas came to Galashiels early after an -year-old boy overheard his mum and granny.Riley Higgins was so moved by the plight of five-year-old Teejay Shaw that he wanted to help.Ever since being diagnosed with rare Perthes disease last August, Teejay has undergone operations and hospital stays.The painful childrens condition, which can last for several years, affects the groin, hips and thighs.Teejay was on holiday in Blackpool during August  when he became unwell and was later diagnosed with the condition at the towns Victoria Hospital.When Riley heard how Teejay had to spend his seaside holiday in hospital he, with help from mum Kim, set up a fundraising page in a bid to send the youngster back to Blackpool with his family for another deserved break.And he is now closing in on his pound target.Teejays mum Selena told us: "Myself and TeeJay were very touched to hear that Riley had decided to set up a fundraiser."For an -year-old boy to think of another child is amazing."Rileyrsquos family should be very proud of the kind and caring young man he is. "At an appointment at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children in Edinburgh in January, a consultant revealed that TeeJays condition had reached its worst stage and he would require a femoral osteotomy to realign the joints in his hips.But during the procedure TeeJays femur broke.After having a plate and pins inserted into his leg, he was unable to walk for nine weeks.Earlier this month the plate and pins were finally removed.And now he is looking forward to ing to Blackpool next year - without any visits to the hospital.Selena added: "Wersquod like to say a massive thank you to Riley and his family for doing this for TeeJay, thank you to everyone who has shared Rileyrsquos go fund me page and a massive thank you to everyone who has donated online or given cash donations."Perthes Disease affects only one in  children with no clear reason why it occurs.Rileys fundraising page has so far raised around pound.You can donate to the TeeJays Travels crowdfunding page at https:www.gofundme f tee-jays-travels
